output.conclusion: This course provides a comprehensive understanding of signals and systems, equipping you with the tools to analyze and design various systems in engineering and related fields.
output.introduction: Welcome to Signals and Systems! This course will explore the fundamental concepts and techniques for analyzing and manipulating signals and systems. We will cover topics ranging from signal representation and system properties to transform analysis and filter design.

chapters.description: Definition of signals, signal classification (continuous-time, discrete-time, periodic, aperiodic, energy, power), basic signal operations (time scaling, time shifting, amplitude scaling).
Unit impulse function, unit step function, ramp function, exponential signals, sinusoidal signals. Their properties and mathematical representations.
Representing signals as a sum of elementary signals. Orthogonal signal spaces. Signal approximation using orthogonal functions.
Definition of systems, system classification (linear, non-linear, time-invariant, time-variant, causal, non-causal, stable, unstable).
Properties of LTI systems, impulse response, convolution integral and summation, cascade and parallel interconnections of LTI systems.
Conditions for stability and causality of LTI systems. Region of convergence (ROC) and its relation to system properties.
Fourier series for periodic signals, Dirichlet conditions, properties of Fourier series (linearity, time shifting, time scaling, differentiation, integration).
Gibbs phenomenon, convergence properties of Fourier series, applications of Fourier series in signal analysis.
Definition and properties of power spectral density (PSD). Calculation of PSD for periodic signals using Fourier series.
Definition of Fourier transform for aperiodic signals, properties of Fourier transform (linearity, time shifting, time scaling, duality, convolution).
Fourier transforms of common signals (impulse, step, exponential, rectangular pulse, sinc function). Parseval's theorem.
Definition and properties of energy spectral density (ESD). Calculation of ESD for aperiodic signals using Fourier transform.
Definition of Laplace transform, region of convergence (ROC), properties of Laplace transform (linearity, time shifting, time scaling, differentiation, integration).
Methods for finding inverse Laplace transform (partial fraction expansion, contour integration). Applications of Laplace transform in circuit analysis.
Definition of system transfer function, poles and zeros, stability analysis using pole locations. Relationship between Laplace transform and Fourier transform.
Definition of Z-transform, region of convergence (ROC), properties of Z-transform (linearity, time shifting, time scaling, differentiation).
Methods for finding inverse Z-transform (partial fraction expansion, power series expansion). Applications of Z-transform in digital signal processing.
System transfer function for discrete-time systems, stability analysis using pole locations, frequency response of discrete-time systems.
